CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Vestibule of Mouth Summary: The provider drains fluid from an abscess, cyst, or hematoma, from the vestibule or anterior most portion of the oral cavity of the patient’s mouth. This procedure involves a simple drainage.

Excision Procedures on the Tongue and Floor of Mouth Summary: In this procedure, the provider makes an incision in the posterior one third of the tongue and excises the affected tissues for the purpose of biopsy.
CPT.explanation: 41105 pertains to biopsy of oral mucosa and/or lesion; vestibule of mouth.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Tongue and Floor of Mouth Summary: In this procedure, the provider excises a lesion from the posterior one thirds of the tongue.
CPT.explanation: 41113 pertains to excision of lesion of floor of mouth.

CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Vestibule of Mouth Summary: The provider removes a foreign body present in the vestibule or anterior most portion of the oral cavity of the patient’s mouth. This procedure involves a simple removal.
CPT.explanation: 40804 pertains to excision of lesion, vestibule of mouth (mucocele).

CPT.description: Incision and Drainage Procedures on the Skin, Subcutaneous and Accessory Structures Summary: The provider open (incises) and drains the contents of a pilonidal cyst.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 10080 – SIMPLE Incision & Drainage of a **Pilonidal** Cyst/Abscess  
Mnemonic: “80 sits on the tail-bone—nowhere else.”

────────────────────────────────────────
1. ONE-LINE DEFINITION  
One midline scalpel incision within the natal cleft (sacrococcygeal “tail-bone”) to evacuate a primary pilonidal abscess, followed by brief irrigation and light packing—nothing more.

2. 5-POINT “MUST MATCH” CHECKLIST  
You may assign 10080 ONLY when every box below is √. Miss one → code something else.

☐ LOCATION ‑ intergluteal / sacrococcygeal cleft ONLY  
☐ INSTRUMENT ‑ scalpel incision (not a needle or catheter)  
☐ COMPLEXITY ‑ single cavity; no branching sinus tracts treated  
☐ CLOSURE ‑ left open or loosely packed; no drains, no flaps  
☐ EXTRAS ‑ no curettage, no seton, no marsupialization

3. QUICK DECISION GRID  

Site of Abscess | Work Performed | CPT
--------------- | -------------- | ----
Any body part EXCEPT natal cleft | Needle aspiration only | 10160
Any body part EXCEPT natal cleft | Scalpel I&D, simple | 10060  
Any body part EXCEPT natal cleft | Scalpel I&D, complicated (multiple loculations, packing, drain, extensive dissection) | 10061  
Natal cleft | Simple scalpel I&D (criteria above all √) | 10080  
Natal cleft | Drain, seton, curettage, multiple tracts, complex | 10081  
Natal cleft | Formal excision of cyst/sinus tract | 11770-11772  
Post-op wound reopened (any site) | 10180  

4. HIGH-YIELD WARNINGS (exam & real life)  
✗ If the documentation says “thigh,” “axilla,” “groin,” “breast,” etc., **10080 is automatically wrong**—choose 10060/10061/10160 as appropriate.  
✗ The word “pilonidal-type” in the note does NOT overrule location. A “pilonidal-type abscess on the thigh” is still NOT 10080.  
✗ Needle only = 10160, even in the natal cleft.  
✗ Use 10081 when the surgeon leaves a Penrose drain, places a seton, performs curettage, or opens several sinus tracts.  
✗ Re-opening a post-operative wound is never 10080; it is 10180.

5. MINI-EXAMPLES  

Code 10080 (correct)  
“Patient prone; 1-cm midline incision in natal cleft overlying fluctuance. Purulence evacuated, cavity irrigated, iodoform wick inserted. No secondary tracts identified.”

Do NOT code 10080 (choose 10060)  
“1.5-cm abscess on anterior thigh; stab incision with #11 blade, pus expressed, packed with ¼-inch gauze.”

Do NOT code 10080 (choose 10160)  
“Axillary abscess aspirated with 18-gauge needle; no incision made.”

6. THREE-QUESTION “DESK STICKER”  
1. Tail-bone cleft?  
2. Scalpel incision?  
3. Simple drain/pack only?  
YES to all → 10080.  
Any NO → look at 10060/10061/10081/10160/10180/11770-11772.

BOTTOM LINE  
10080 is a **location-restricted** code. If the abscess is not in the natal cleft, 10080 is never the answer—no matter how simple or complex the drainage.

CPT.description: Fine Needle Aspiration Biopsy Procedures Summary: The provider performs a fine needle aspiration (FNA), a diagnostic procedure that involves collecting a small number of cells, a small amount of tissue, or fluid from a cyst or mass using a specialized needle and syringe. Report this code for the first lesion biopsied.

Incision and Drainage Procedures on the Skin, Subcutaneous and Accessory Structures Summary: The provider incises the area of abscess and drains the collection of pus from a lesion, such as a carbuncle, hidradenitis, cyst, furuncle, or paronychia, with the help of surgical instruments. A simple incision and drainage usually involves a single incision of an abscess situated just below the skin's surface.
CPT.explanation: 10060 is the CPT code for incision and drainage of abscess (e.g., carbuncle, suppurative hidradenitis, cutaneous or subcutaneous abscess, cyst, furuncle, or paronychia); simple or single.

CPT.description: Incision and Drainage Procedures on the Skin, Subcutaneous and Accessory Structures Summary: The provider inserts a needle into a fluid deposit area on the skin and aspirates fluid or pus to obtain a culture.

CPT.explanation:
══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
CPT 20005  –  Incision & Drainage, Superficial Collection, LOWER-LEG / ANKLE
══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
WHAT IT PAYS FOR – ONE-LINE SUMMARY
A single, skin-level incision that releases an abscess, seroma, hematoma, or
inflamed bursa located BETWEEN the knee-joint line and the malleoli, with no
drain left in place and no deep-tissue work.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. THE THREE “MUST-ANSWER-YES” QUESTIONS
   1. Anatomic Zone …  Distal leg only  
      • Key words: calf, shin, Achilles area, ankle, medial / lateral
        malleolus.  
      • If you can palpate the patella → TOO HIGH → use 20002.  
      • If you can shake the patient’s hand (upper arm / elbow) → use 20010.  

   2. Depth …  Skin-to-subcutaneous only  
      • No fascia or muscle dissection, no compartment entered.  
      • If the note says “deep” OR “drain left in situ” → 20006.  

   3. Technique …  Simple I&D  
      • One incision, break up loculations, irrigate, pack or leave open,
        simple closure at most.  
      • Counter-incisions, layered closure, or endoscopy → different code.  

   MISS ANY “YES”?  SHIFT CODES
      Above knee: 20002  
      Upper arm / elbow: 20010  
      Deep or drain left: 20006  
      Any other body area: 10060 / 10061  

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2. MOST-FAILED EXAM PAIR:  20005 vs 20010  (Put this on your monitor!)
   • 20005  =  DISTAL – shin / ankle – “I’m working near the cleats.”  
   • 20010  =  PROXIMAL – upper arm / elbow – “I can shake the pt’s hand.”  

   NEVER code a football-collision hematoma of the UPPER ARM as 20005.
   That scenario = textbook 20010.  Audit teams flag this mix-up daily.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3. HARD STOPS & RED FLAGS  
   • “Drain left in place” or “deep lateral compartment opened” → 20006.  
   • Document says only “leg abscess” → query; cannot defend 20005.  
   • Any mention of patella, knee bursa, or thigh → 20002, not 20005.  
   • If the physician dictates “upper-arm hematoma” even once → 20010.  

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4. DOCUMENTATION QUICK-CHECK  (have ALL 3 or query)
   ☐ Specific distal-leg term (calf / shin / ankle / malleolus)  
   ☐ Depth descriptor (superficial, subcutaneous, bursal)  
   ☐ Simple I&D, no drain left  

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5. EXAMPLES THAT PASS / FAIL
   ✓ “3-cm purulent seroma, right calf; 1-cm incision, blunt dissection,
      irrigation, iodoform packing.”            →  20005  
   ✓ “Posterior ankle bursitis abscess; superficial I&D, no drain.”  
                                                →  20005  
   ✗ “Hematoma, upper arm from football tackle; 2-cm incision evacuated.”  
      Correct code = 20010 (NOT 20005)  
   ✗ “Deep intramuscular calf abscess; counter-incision, Penrose placed.”  
      Correct code = 20006  

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
6. GLOBAL PACKAGE
   • 10-day global.  
   • Includes incision, drainage, manual breakup of loculations, irrigation,
     simple packing or closure.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
7. LIGHTNING DECISION TREE
   DISTAL leg?           NO → 20002 or 20010 or 10060/10061  
   YES → Superficial?    NO → 20006  
   YES → Simple I&D?     NO → 20006  
   YES → 20005

══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
BOTTOM-LINE MANTRA
“20005 lives below the knee, stays skin-deep, and goes home drain-free.  
Upper arm?  20010.  Deep or complex?  20006.”  
Memorize this and you will never mix them up.
══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

================================================================================
CPT 20010 – INCISION & DRAINAGE (I&D) OF HEMATOMA, SEROMA, OR OTHER  
TRAUMATIC / POST-OPERATIVE FLUID COLLECTION – UPPER ARM OR ELBOW –  
OPEN, DEEP (THROUGH FASCIA)  
================================================================================

QUICK DEFINITION  
“20010 is a brand-new operating-room incision that goes THROUGH THE FASCIA
anywhere between the shoulder joint above and the tip of the olecranon below.”

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
1. WHAT 20010 PAYS FOR
• Creation of a NEW incision that cuts all three layers: skin → sub-Q fat → investing fascia.  
• Entry into an intramuscular, intermuscular, or sub-fascial cavity in the UPPER ARM or ELBOW.  
• Complete evacuation (and lysis of loculations if needed), copious irrigation, limited
  debridement if documented, and placement of drain or packing.  
• Simple skin closure. (Intermediate/complex closure may be billed separately.)

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
2. “FENCEPOST” ANATOMIC LIMITS – MEMORIZE
   PROXIMAL: Just distal to the glenohumeral (shoulder) joint   
   DISTAL:   Tip of the olecranon (elbow)

If the incision is even a few centimeters proximal to the shoulder joint or distal onto
the forearm, 20010 is WRONG—look for the region-specific code instead.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
3. 3-POINT “QUICK CHECK” BEFORE YOU CHOOSE 20010
1️⃣ SITE  Does the note clearly say “upper arm” or “elbow” (with laterality)?  
2️⃣ DEPTH  Was the fascia opened or do you see words such as “intramuscular,”
            “intermuscular,” “sub-fascial,” or “deep space”?  
3️⃣ NEW CUT Is a new incision described OR is there a modifier 58/78/79 explanation?

YES to all three → 20010 is defensible.  
ANY “NO” → Stop. Find the correct code below.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
4. MINIMUM WORDING YOU MUST SEE IN THE OP NOTE
• Exact site + laterality (e.g., “left distal posterior upper arm”)  
• Confirmation of fascial entry (“fascia divided, cavity identified in intramuscular plane”)  
• Fluid type / estimated volume removed  
• Irrigation + drain or packing details  
• Statement that this was a NEW incision (or modifier explanation)

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
5. HIGH-YIELD EXAM & REAL-WORLD “GOTCHAS”
• “THIGH” IS NEVER 20010. Deep I&D of the thigh or around the knee = 27301.  
  › Many exams purposely omit 27301 to trap you into picking 20010 or 20016.  
  › If 27301 is missing, reread the stem: the collection may be superficial
    (code 10140/10160) or the test writer made an error—do NOT default to 20010.  

• “NEAR THE ELBOW” ≠ “ELBOW.” If the incision is on the proximal FOREARM,
  use 25028 (forearm/wrist), not 20010.

• SUPERFICIAL COLLECTIONS (skin ± sub-Q only) are coded 10140 (seroma/hematoma)
  or 10160 (abscess)—never 20010.

• Re-opening a recent incision during the global period is bundled unless modifier 78 criteria are met.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
6. MOST COMMONLY CONFUSED CODES – HOW TO TELL THEM APART

Code   | Region/Depth                               | Clues in Dictation
-------|--------------------------------------------|-----------------------------
23030  | Shoulder / Axilla – deep                   | “deltoid,” “axilla,” “rotator”
20010  | Upper Arm / Elbow – deep (THIS CODE)       | “biceps,” “triceps,” “brachialis”
25028  | Forearm / Wrist – deep                     | “flexor compartment,” “radius/ulna”
27301  | Thigh / Knee – deep                        | “quadriceps,” “hamstring,” “vastus”
27030  | Hip / Buttock – deep                       | “gluteus,” “piriformis,” “hip”
27603  | Leg / Ankle – deep                         | “gastrocnemius,” “soleus,” “tibia”
20016  | Trunk / Back / Abdominal wall – deep when no
        region-specific code exists                 | “thoracic wall,” “lumbar fascia”
10140/10160 | ANY LOCATION – superficial            | No fascial entry

WARNING ON 20055 & 20005  
• 20055 and 20005 involve I&D around fixation devices or bone cortex—
  they do NOT substitute for thigh, leg, or arm seroma drainage.  
  If the op note never mentions pins, wires, or bone cortex, cross these off.

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
7. FAST DECISION TREE
Deep I&D (fascial entry) present?  
 └─ NO → 10140 / 10160  
 └─ YES → What anatomic zone?  
   Upper arm / Elbow → 20010 ✅  
   Forearm / Wrist  → 25028  
   Shoulder / Axilla → 23030  
   Thigh / Knee    → 27301  
   Hip / Buttock   → 27030  
   Leg / Ankle    → 27603  
   Trunk / Back   → 20016  

──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
8. MEMORY HOOK
“20010 lives BETWEEN two joints: shoulder above, elbow below.  
Anything higher, lower, or on the thigh—LET IT GO!”

Carry this hierarchy into every exam and you’ll never code a thigh seroma with 20010 (or 20055) again.

─────────────────────────  CPT 20020  –  Incision & Removal of Foreign Body, Subcutaneous Tissue ( SIMPLE “STAB-AND-GRAB” )  ─────────────────────────

1. PLAIN-ENGLISH CORE  
   • One tiny skin nick (≤ 1 cm).  
   • Knife passes ONLY into subcutaneous fat; fascia is never seen.  
   • Surgeon plucks out an inert, NON-living object (splinter, glass, gravel, metal, plastic, bullet fragment, etc.).  
   • Wound is either left open or closed with a single, one-layer suture.  
   • No undermining, no enlargement of the wound, no tissue excision, no drain.

2. THE “S-O-S” RULE – YOU MUST SEE ALL THREE LETTERS IN THE OP NOTE  
   S Subcutaneous ONLY (knife stops at fat; fascia, muscle, tendon, bone untouched)  
   O Object is NON-living (wood, glass, metal, stone, lead, plastic, etc.)  
   S Simple Technique (≤ 1 cm stab; zero debridement; no layered closure)  
   If any letter is missing, 20020 is automatically wrong.

3. HARD-STOP WORD LIST – ONE APPEARANCE = DISCARD 20020  
   cyst ganglion lipoma neuroma nodule tumor mass abscess hematoma seroma implant hardware  
   These represent LIVING tissue, fluid collections, or previously implanted devices and are coded elsewhere.

4. MOST COMMON MIX-UPS – QUICK “THIS-OR-THAT” GUIDE  

   • Living lump (cyst, lipoma, ganglion, tumor)  
     – If in epidermis/dermis → 11400-11446 (benign skin-lesion excision)  
     – If subcutaneous in arm/shoulder → 24071-24079 series*  
     – If ganglion near wrist/hand  → 25111-25112  
     – If inside bone       → 20055  
     *Use anatomic equivalents for other regions (25071-25079, 26115-26116, etc.).

   • Liquid pus/blood (abscess, hematoma, seroma)  
     – Superficial (subcutaneous) → 20005  
     – Deep (beneath fascia)   → 20010  

   • Foreign body past fascia (embedded in muscle/tendon)  
     → 20520 / 20525  

   • Foreign body inside bone  → 20680 (hardware) or 20661 (deep implant) as appropriate.

5. RAPID DECISION TREE  

   1) What is being removed?  
        Inert object → continue      Living tissue or fluid → NOT 20020  
   2) Where does the scalpel stop?  
        Subcutaneous fat only → continue  Past fascia → NOT 20020  
   3) How big is the incision / how complex is the closure?  
        ≤ 1 cm, simple → 20020     > 1 cm, layered, debridement → different code  

6. DOCUMENTATION CHECKLIST – VERIFY BEFORE YOU CODE 20020  
   ☐ Operative note names a NON-living foreign body.  
   ☐ Location limited to subcutaneous fat; fascia explicitly NOT violated.  
   ☐ Incision size ≤ 1 cm; no wound enlargement, debridement, or tissue excision.  
   ☐ Closure (if any) is one-layer/simple.  
   If any box is unchecked, abandon 20020.

7. EXAM-DAY SAFETY MANTRA  
   “SEE a splinter – 20020.  
    SEE a cyst – run away fast.”  

8. REAL-WORLD ILLUSTRATIONS  

   ✓ Correct 20020:  
     “3 mm stab incision dorsum right forearm; 5 mm glass shard retrieved from subcutis; skin closed with one 4-0 nylon suture. No fascia exposed.”  

   ✗ NOT 20020 (choose lesion-excision code):  
     “2 cm epidermoid cyst excised from subcutaneous tissue of upper arm with layered closure.”  

   ✗ NOT 20020 (choose deep FB removal code):  
     “Removal of bullet fragment lodged within biceps muscle; 4 cm incision carried through fascia and muscle.”  

9. MEMORY HOOK  
   “Stab, Snatch, Simple-close—20020.  
    Anything living or deeper? Pick another code.”

CPT.description: Chemistry Procedures Summary: Sugar in the bloodstream can get attached to the hemoglobin in red blood cells. Once the sugar is attached, it stays there for the lifetime of the red blood cell (around 120 days or over 3 months). The higher the amount of blood sugar, the more the quantity of sugar attached to the blood cells. This A1C test measures the amount of sugar sticking to the red blood cells, displaying the result as a percentage. This gives the physician an understanding about the blood sugar level of the patient for the preceding three months. A normal, healthy person should have A1C level below 7%.
CPT.explanation: Code 83036 is for the Hemoglobin A1c test. The other codes are not specific to the Hemoglobin A1c test and represent different laboratory tests.

CPT.description: Chemistry Procedures Summary: The analyst tests for the presence of hemoglobin F, typically in a whole blood sample. The amount is usually very low, except in the newborn infant, in whom almost all the hemoglobin is type F.

Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: This is a procedure involving surgical removal of a part of one of the two lobes the thyroid gland is divided into. The provider may perform the procedure with or without surgical removal of the isthmus, the tissue connecting the two lobes of the thyroid gland in the middle.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60210, refers to a partial thyroidectomy. While 60212 describes a complete thyroid lobectomy, 60100 is for a thyroid biopsy, and 60225 pertains to a thyroid lobectomy with contralateral subtotal lobectomy. In this scenario, only a partial thyroidectomy was performed, making 60210 the appropriate code.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: The procedure involves surgical removal of a part of one lobe of the thyroid gland and most of the portion of the other lobe of the thyroid gland. The provider also performs surgical removal of the isthmus, the tissue connecting the two lobes of the thyroid gland in the middle.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60100, refers to a fine needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid. In contrast, 60240 describes a complete thyroidectomy, 60220 is for a thyroid lobectomy, and 60212 is for a complete thyroid lobectomy with isthmusectomy. The question explicitly mentions a biopsy, making 60100 the right choice.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: This is a procedure involving complete surgical removal of one of the two lobes the thyroid gland is divided into. The provider may perform the procedure with or without surgical removal of the isthmus, the tissue connecting the two lobes of the thyroid gland in the middle.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 60220  
Thyroid lobectomy, unilateral; TOTAL lobectomy (entire lobe removed), with or without removal of the isthmus.

Key Points for Accurate Use  
1. “Total lobectomy” = the ENTIRE lobe is taken out. If the operative note says the surgeon removed the whole right or left lobe, choose 60220.  
2. The term “lobectomy” in the endocrine surgery literature almost always means the whole lobe unless the surgeon explicitly states “partial.” Do not assume “lobectomy” is partial.

Commonly Confused Codes  
• 60210 – PARTIAL thyroid lobectomy, unilateral, with or without isthmusectomy. Use when only a PORTION of one lobe is excised (e.g., upper pole resection, wedge resection).  
• 60212 – TOTAL lobectomy on one side + SUBTOTAL lobectomy on the opposite side (used in staged/extent-of-disease cases).  
• 60225 – TOTAL lobectomy on one side + PARTIAL lobectomy on the opposite side.  
• 60240 – Total thyroidectomy (both lobes completely removed).  
• 60100 – Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy of thyroid; no open resection.

Quick Decision Checklist  
A. Entire gland removed? → 60240  
B. One entire lobe removed? → 60220  
C. Only part of one lobe removed? → 60210  
D. One entire lobe + some of the contralateral lobe removed?  
 • Subtotal other side → 60212  
 • Partial other side  → 60225  
E. Needle biopsy only? → 60100

Documentation Tips  
• Look for operative phrases such as “complete removal of the right lobe,” “total lobectomy,” or “remaining thyroid tissue on that side was excised in its entirety.”  
• If the report says “partial lobectomy,” “hemithyroidectomy” with residual tissue, or specifies a polar/segmental resection, it is NOT 60220.  
• Verify whether the isthmus was removed; it does NOT change the code selection for 60210 or 60220.

Coder’s Warning  
The most frequent error is defaulting to 60210 whenever the word “lobectomy” appears. Always confirm whether the entire lobe was removed. If the surgeon is ambiguous, query for clarification before coding.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: The procedure involves surgical removal of one whole lobe of the thyroid gland and most of the other lobe of the thyroid gland. The provider also performs surgical removal of the isthmus, the tissue connecting the two lobes of the thyroid gland in the middle.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60210, refers to a partial thyroidectomy. While 60212 describes a complete thyroid lobectomy, 60100 is for a thyroid biopsy, and 60225 pertains to a thyroid lobectomy with contralateral subtotal lobectomy. In this scenario, only a partial thyroidectomy was performed, making 60210 the appropriate code.

CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Kidney Summary: The provider examines the kidney for diagnostic purposes, without any curative surgical intervention, such as inspection for hemorrhage, urinary leakage, or tissue damage due to trauma.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 50010 – Renal Exploration, Open (with or without intra-operative biopsy)

What the code represents  
• An open surgical incision that allows the surgeon to directly inspect, palpate, decompress, control hemorrhage, repair injury, or obtain a wedge biopsy of the kidney.  
• May include limited intra-operative imaging of the collecting system performed through the operative field (e.g., a quick nephrostogram done through the incision), but it does NOT include formal vascular catheterization or angiography.

When to use 50010  
• Flank incision to explore a kidney after blunt trauma to rule out laceration or active bleeding.  
• Open exploration for unexplained renal mass or hydronephrosis when the operative plan is “look first, decide later.”  
• Conversion of a planned minimally invasive procedure to an open exploration solely to visualize the kidney without removing it.

Common look-alikes and how to keep them straight  
• Selective renal angiography (diagnostic study of the renal arteries)  
  – Code from the interventional radiology series (e.g., 36251-36254 for catheter placement + 75722 for imaging).  
  – No surgical incision into the kidney. If a case report says “diagnostic renal angiography,” 50010 is WRONG.  
• 50398 – Injection procedure for an antegrade nephrostogram/ureterogram  
  – Contrast injected through an existing nephrostomy tube to study the collecting system.  
  – Performed percutaneously, no surgical exploration.  
• 50200 – Percutaneous (needle) renal biopsy  
  – Small-gauge needle through the skin, usually with imaging guidance. No open incision.  
• 50220 – Nephrectomy, partial or total  
  – Removal of kidney tissue. If any portion of the kidney is excised with intent to remove, use a nephrectomy code, not 50010.

Red-flag phrases that tell you 50010 is NOT the answer  
“Catheter advanced into renal artery…contrast injected” → Think 36251-36254 + 75722.  
“Contrast injected through nephrostomy tube”     → 50398.  
“Core biopsy needle under CT guidance”       → 50200.  
“Kidney removed/partial nephrectomy performed”   → 50220 series.

Quick rule of thumb  
If you can put your hand on the kidney through an incision but you do NOT remove it, you are in 50010 territory. If you are only injecting contrast or working through a catheter or needle, look elsewhere.

CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Kidney Summary: The provider drains an abscess from the kidney (renal) or the area surrounding the kidney (perirenal) with an open approach.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50543, refers to a percutaneous nephrostolithotomy or pyelostolithotomy. The other codes are: 50010 - Renal exploratory surgery, 50020 - Renal abscess drainage, and 50200 - Renal biopsy.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Kidney Summary: In this procedure.  A physician inserts a collection needle into the kidney to collect a sample for further diagnostic biopsy.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 51600, pertains to cystography. The other codes are: 50395 - Injection procedure for nephrostogram or ureterogram, 50250 - Ablation, renal tumor, unilateral, percutaneous, and 50200 - Renal biopsy.

CPT.description: Laparoscopic Procedures on the Kidney Summary: The provider uses a surgical laparoscopic technique to remove part of a kidney.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50543, refers to a percutaneous nephrostolithotomy or pyelostolithotomy. The other codes are: 50010 - Renal exploratory surgery, 50020 - Renal abscess drainage, and 50200 - Renal biopsy.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Kidney Summary: Nephrectomy is a surgical procedure for removal of a kidney or part of a kidney.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50200, refers to a renal biopsy. The other codes are: 50220 - Nephrectomy, 50225 - Delayed nephrostogram, and 50230 - Nephrectomy, partial.

The correct code, 50010, refers to renal exploratory surgery. 50220 describes a nephrectomy, 50200 is for a renal biopsy, and 50398 describes an injection procedure for antegrade nephrostogram and/or ureterogram.

CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Nose Summary: In this procedure, the provider aspirates the excess fluid from within the nasal cavity, which may be due to an abscess or hematoma.
Excision Procedures on the Nose Summary: This CPT code is for a submucous resection of the inferior turbinate (partial or complete by any method).
Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity to examine the structures of the nasal cavity on one or both sides.
CPT.explanation: 31231 is the CPT code for nasal endoscopy, diagnostic, unilateral or bilateral (separate procedure).

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity. She examines the nasal contents. The provider then performs a nasal biopsy, polypectomy, or debridement.
Incision Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider makes an intranasal incision. The provider then uses cutting forceps to perform a middle meatal sinusotomy.

Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity. He then gains access to the maxillary sinus through a cut in the uncinate process. The provider opens the maxillary sinus.
CPT.explanation:
31256 ‒ Nasal/Sinus Endoscopy, Surgical; WITH MAXILLARY ANTROSTOMY  
(Endoscopic middle-meatal antrostomy)

What the code represents  
• Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) performed trans-nasally with a rigid/flexible endoscope.  
• The surgeon enters the middle meatus, removes the uncinate process if necessary, identifies the NATURAL ostium of the maxillary sinus, and enlarges it to improve ventilation/drainage.  
• No external (facial) or intra-oral incision is made.

Included services (bundled)  
– Diagnostic nasal endoscopy  
– Uncinectomy / uncinate process resection  
– Limited removal of bone or mucosa needed only to create the opening  
– Hemostasis and simple postoperative debridement

When to code something else  
31267  – If the surgeon also removes significant diseased tissue, polyps, or fungal debris from INSIDE the maxillary sinus.  
31020  – Open (non-endoscopic) Caldwell-Luc maxillary sinusotomy via a sublabial or facial incision with removal of the anterior-inferior sinus wall. No scope = no 31256.  
31287 / 31288 – Endoscopic SPHENOIDOTOMY procedures.  
31254 / 31255 – Endoscopic ETHMOIDECTOMY procedures.

Key documentation words that support 31256  
“Endoscopic,” “transnasal,” “middle meatal antrostomy,” “natural ostium enlarged,” “FESS,” “uncinectomy.”  
Red flags that point to 31020 instead: “Caldwell-Luc,” “sublabial incision,” “gingivobuccal incision,” “anterior wall removed.”

Real-world example  
Operative note: “Using a 0° endoscope, the uncinate process was removed. The natural ostium of the right maxillary sinus was identified and widened to 10 mm for drainage.”  → 31256.

Quick check  
Is an endoscope documented? YES → 31 256.  
Was the sinus entered through an open sublabial or facial incision? YES → 31 020, not 31 256.

Use this distinction—ENDOSCOPIC vs. OPEN approach—to avoid the common 31020/31256 mix-up.

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity and creates an opening in the sphenoid sinus.

Endoscopy Procedures on the Accessory Sinuses Summary: In this procedure, the provider inserts an endoscope into the nasal cavity. The provider widens the sphenoid sinus opening. He then removes tissues from the sphenoid sinus.
Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: The procedure involves surgical removal of the entire thyroid gland.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 60100, refers to a fine needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid. In contrast, 60240 describes a complete thyroidectomy, 60220 is for a thyroid lobectomy, and 60212 is for a complete thyroid lobectomy with isthmusectomy. The question explicitly mentions a biopsy, making 60100 the right choice.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Thyroid Gland Summary: This is a diagnostic procedure in which the provider removes a tissue sample from the thyroid gland, typically under imaging guidance, using an automatic, spring–powered core needle.

In contrast, 60240 describes a complete thyroidectomy, 60220 is for a thyroid lobectomy, and 60212 is for a complete thyroid lobectomy with isthmusectomy. CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Parathyroid, Thymus, Adrenal Glands, Pancreas, and Carotid Body Summary: In the traditional procedure of parathyroid exploration, the provider surgically visualizes and screens the parathyroid glands for pathology based on their appearance and relative size. He may then perform parathyroidectomy, which is surgical removal of one or more parathyroid glands as indicated. The glands are a set of four small glands situated on the rear of the four corners of the butterfly shaped thyroid gland.

While 60212 and 60240 are associated with thyroid procedures (thyroid lobectomy with isthmusectomy and total thyroidectomy respectively), 60100 is for a thyroid biopsy. The scenario specifies a procedure on the parathyroid, making 60500 the accurate code.

CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50430, refers to injection procedure for retrograde pyelography. The other codes are: 50320 - Renal autotransplantation, 50200 - Renal biopsy, and 50390 - Aspiration of kidney cyst.

CPT.description: Other Renal Introduction (Injection/Change/Removal) Procedures Summary: The provider creates a new access route percutaneously (through a small incision made in the patient’s skin) and injects contrast material into the ureters (ureterogram) or kidney (nephrostogram) to analyze the internal structures of the kidneys, renal pelvis, and/or ureters using imaging guidance. The provider typically performs this procedure to assess nephrostomy or pyelostomy tube function, identify blockage in the ureteropelvic junction, or check for urine leakage around the tube insertion site. CPT.description: Established Patient Summary: Preventive medicine services are provided to individuals who are not in need of any immediate medical attention, but need to undergo a periodic health checkup as a preventive measure. Well–baby visits, well–woman visits, and routine annual physical check–ups come under the purview of preventive medicine reevaluation and management services. These visits are different from other visits where the patient has a problem for which medical attention is sought. The age, gender, and associated risk factors of the person are important considerations while providing a preventive medicine service. The physician performs a comprehensive review of systems, comprehensive past family and social history (PFSH), and makes a thorough assessment of age and gender–related risk factors. The physician may order and obtain diagnostic/laboratory procedures and administer immunizations during the preventive service.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99381 is for a comprehensive preventive medicine evaluation and management for new patients. 99391 is for established patients, 99382 is for new patients aged 1-4, and 99392 is for established patients aged 1-4.

CPT.description: New Patient Summary: The provider performs a well–patient visit for a child who is between the ages of 1 and 4 who meets the definition of new patient.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99381 is for a comprehensive preventive medicine evaluation and management for new patients. 99391 is for established patients, 99382 is for new patients aged 1-4, and 99392 is for established patients aged 1-4.

Well–baby visits, well–woman visits, and routine annual physical check–ups come under the purview of preventive medicine reevaluation and management services. These visits are different from other visits where the patient has a problem for which medical attention is sought. The age, gender, and associated risk factors of the person are important considerations while providing a preventive medicine service. The physician may order and obtain diagnostic/laboratory procedures and administer immunizations during the preventive service.

CPT.description: New Patient Summary: The provider performs a well–baby visit for a child under the age of one.
CPT.explanation:
CPT® 99381-99397  
Preventive Medicine Services – Initial / Periodic  
(“Well-baby,” well-child, school, sports, camp, routine or annual physical)

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
THE “TRIPLE-LOCK” RULE – EVERY NOTE MUST SHOW ALL THREE, IN WRITING
1. Service TYPE: visit is preventive (NOT problem-oriented).  
2. Patient STATUS to THIS practice / specialty  
      • NEW  = no face-to-face visit in ≥3 cal. yrs → choose 9938x series  
      • EST  = face-to-face visit within 3 yrs      → choose 9939x series  
3. Exact AGE on the DOS (either DOB or “age X yrs Y mos”).

If just one element is missing, a 9938x/9939x code is invalid.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
AGE & STATUS BUILD THE CODE – EASY “ZIP-CODE” FORMULA
• First digit  = 9 (always).  
• Second digit = 9 (always).  
• Third digit  = 3 (always).  
• Fourth digit = 8 if NEW, 9 if EST.  
• Fifth digit  = written age category below.

          NEW PATIENT                  ESTABLISHED PATIENT
  < 1 yr   99381                  < 1 yr   99391
  1-4 yr   99382                  1-4 yr   99392
  5-11 yr  99383                  5-11 yr  99393
  12-17 yr 99384                  12-17 yr 99394
  18-39 yr 99385                  18-39 yr 99395
  40-64 yr 99386                  40-64 yr 99396
  65+ yr   99387                  65+ yr   99397

ABSOLUTE BOARD / CLAIMS RULE  
No documented age or DOB → no preventive code. Never infer age from words
such as “annual,” “pediatric,” grade level, vaccine schedule, or parental
presence. If age is absent, choose “coding indeterminable” or the
non-preventive option supplied.

EXAM’S FAVORITE TRICK  
Vignette: “Olivia went to the pediatrician for her annual check-up.
Comprehensive past, family and social history obtained.” AGE NOT STATED → 
Correct response: “Cannot be determined” (or use the non-preventive
alternative). Wrong but tempting answers: 99391, 99392, etc.

Sticky-note mantra: STATUS + WRITTEN AGE … or walk away.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
WHAT 99381-99397 ALREADY INCLUDE
• Comprehensive, age-appropriate history & physical.  
• Anticipatory guidance / risk-factor counseling.  
• Ordering of routine screening labs / immunizations.  
Therefore, counting ROS bullets, PFSH depth, or exam systems never bumps
the code up—those items are bundled.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
WHEN TO ADD OTHER CODES
• Separately addressed acute/chronic problem → 9920x-9921x with ‑25.  
• Vaccine administration (90460-90474) & vaccine supplies (90476-90759)
  when documented.

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
FREQUENT LOOK-ALIKES & HOW TO TELL THEM APART
99202-99215  Diagnosis-driven; selected by MDM, not age.  
99401-99404  Counseling only; no comprehensive exam.  
99455-99456  Disability / work clearance, non-preventive purpose.  
99281-99285  ED setting, urgent/emergent problems.  
99460-99463  Newborn inpatient or birthing-center care (first 28 days).

────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
SPEED-CHECK EXAMPLES
• First visit, 6-month-old → NEW <1 yr → 99381  
• Yearly well-child, 3-year-old seen last year → EST 1-4 yr → 99392  
• Sports physical, 15-year-old never seen before → NEW 12-17 yr → 99384  
• New patient physical, 52-year-old → NEW 40-64 yr → 99386  
• Scenario lacks written age → Preventive code NOT reportable.

REMEMBER: NO AGE, NO CODE.

CPT.description: Organ or Disease Oriented Panels Summary: The lab analyst performs a comprehensive metabolic panel, or CMP test in which he measures the blood level of 14 chemicals the code descriptor lists for the panel.
CPT.explanation: Code 80053 is for a comprehensive metabolic panel. The other codes represent different types of lab panels or tests and are not specifically for a comprehensive metabolic panel.

CPT.description: Organ or Disease Oriented Panels Summary: The lab analyst performs an electrolyte panel; this panel must include measurement of carbon dioxide, chloride, potassium, and sodium.

Organ or Disease Oriented Panels Summary: The lab analyst performs testing for the specific group of clinical laboratory procedures in the general health panel. Payers typically consider 80050 to apply only when the clinician orders the general health panel specifically as a screening, so the panel code would not apply when the clinician orders the component tests for diagnostic purposes.

Organ or Disease Oriented Panels Summary: The lab analyst performs an obstetric panel; this panel must include tests for a complete blood count with differential, a hepatitis B surface antigen, a rubella antibody, a qualitative non treponemal syphilis test, a red blood cell antibody screen, ABO blood typing, and Rh typing.

Excision Procedures on the Nose Summary: In this procedure the provider removes a nasal polyp or polyps from within the nasal cavity. The provider performs this procedure to remove the obstruction that the polyp is causing.
CPT.explanation:
30110  –  Excision or Surgical Planing of Nasal Polyp(s), Simple (Intranasal, NON-endoscopic)

What the code represents  
• Cold-steel or powered (“microdebrider”) removal of one or more nasal polyps via a direct intranasal approach.  
• Surgeon works under headlight, loupe, or operating microscope—but NOT through a rigid or flexible endoscope.  
• May be unilateral or bilateral; code once per operative session (do not add modifiers –RT/–LT).  
• Includes local infiltration, hemostasis, and minor mucosal trimming/planing performed at the same time.

When to use it  
• “Office” or simple ambulatory polypectomy where the physician directly visualizes the polyp(s) without formal nasal/sinus endoscopy.  
• No concurrent ethmoidectomy, maxillary antrostomy, or other sinus work.

Codes it is commonly confused with—and how to tell them apart  
• 31237  Nasal/Sinus Endoscopy, surgical; with polypectomy or debridement  
  – ALWAYS performed with an endoscope.  
  – Usually follows or is part of functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS).  
  – If you see wording such as “endoscopic,” “FESS,” “nasal/sinus endoscope inserted,” or CPT 3123x elsewhere in the op note, 31237—not 30110—is appropriate.  
  – Mutually Exclusive Edit: 30110 and 31237 cannot be reported together on the same side during the same encounter.
• 30140  Submucous resection of inferior turbinate(s)  
  – Procedure is directed at the turbinate, not at polyps.  
  – Look for terms “SMR,” “inferior turbinate reduction,” or “submucosal resection.”
• 30220  Limited intranasal antrostomy  
  – Entry into the maxillary sinus, not simple intranasal polyp excision.  
  – Often accompanied by phrases “antrostomy,” “middle meatus,” or “maxillary sinusotomy.”

Documentation tips for 30110  
• Op-note should clearly state “simple intranasal polypectomy” or “polyp removed under direct visualization.”  
• Absence of the word “endoscope” is critical—if an endoscope is used, code 31237.  
• Specify “no sinus work performed” to reinforce that 30110 is the correct standalone code.

Real-world example  
“Using a nasal speculum and headlight, the right nasal cavity was inspected. A solitary polyp arising from the middle meatus was grasped with Takahashi forceps and excised. Hemostasis achieved with cautery. No endoscope utilized. The left side was normal.”

Bill 30110 once.

CPT.description: New or Established Patient Summary: The provider sees a patient for an initial hospital inpatient or observation care visit involving evaluation and management (E/M). The visit involves a straightforward or low level of medical decision making or the provider spends at least 40 minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99223 is for a comprehensive level of history-taking and examination for patients in hospitals. 99221 is for a detailed history, 99222 is for an expanded problem-focused history, and 99220 is for observation or inpatient hospital care.

CPT code 99223 is for a comprehensive level of history-taking and examination for patients in hospitals. 99221 is for a detailed history, 99218 is for a problem-focused history, and 99220 is for observation or inpatient hospital care.

CPT.description: New or Established Patient Summary: The provider sees a patient for an initial hospital inpatient or observation care visit involving evaluation and management (E/M). The visit involves a high level of medical decision making or the provider spends at least 75 minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation:
99223 — Initial Hospital Inpatient OR Observation Care – LEVEL 3  
“The HIGH-MDM / 75-Minute Admit” (2024 rules)

================================================================
1. ONE-LINE SNAPSHOT  
First-calendar-day hospital OR observation encounter by the attending that involves ❶ HIGH-complexity Medical Decision Making or ❷ ≥ 75 minutes of the physician’s same-day work.

Mnemonic: H igh MDM or H our-plus (75 min) → 99223

================================================================
2. BILLING GATEKEEPERS (ALL must be “YES” before leveling)  
□ Signed, date- & time-stamped admit/obs ORDER written by you.  
□ You are the ATTENDING/primary team for that calendar day (consultants code 99252-99255 or 99221-99223 + -AI modifier on attending).  
□ It is the PATIENT’S FIRST inpatient/obs calendar day. (Subsequent days = 99231-99233.)  

================================================================
3. TWO VALID PATHS TO 99223

A. BY MEDICAL DECISION MAKING – ALL THREE ELEMENTS = HIGH  
• Number/Complexity of PROBLEMS: Acute or chronic illness with threat to life or bodily function (e.g., STEMI, sepsis, massive PE, GI bleed with drop in Hb).  
• DATA to review/order: Extensive – multiple labs, advanced imaging, external records, independent interpretation, discussions with another clinician, etc.  
• RISK of complications/morbidity/mortality: High – emergent surgery, IV anticoag/vasoactive drips, BiPAP/vent, chemo, DNR/goals-of-care decisions, etc.

B. BY TOTAL PHYSICIAN TIME – ≥ 75 MINUTES  
Count ALL work personally performed on the calendar date: chart review, bedside, family conferences, care-coordination, orders, documentation.  
Document explicitly:  
“Total physician time on 06-Mar-2024: 82 minutes ( >50 % counseling/coordination).”

================================================================
4. WHAT **DOES NOT** DETERMINE THE CODE (Post-2023 E/M rules)

✘ Depth of History & Exam. Only “medically appropriate” is required; number of ROS systems, bullets, or exam elements NO LONGER affect 99221-99223 selection.  
✘ Lengthy templates or copy-paste. Auditors ignore fluff and score by MDM or time.  
✘ A dramatic-sounding diagnosis alone (e.g., “chest pain”). Code to the demonstrated severity and management, not the chief complaint.

BIG RED FLAG: “Extended history + detailed exam” with LOW or MODERATE MDM still codes 99221 or 99222—not 99223. This is the most common audit failure.

================================================================
5. CODE-CONFUSION QUICK GUIDE

• 99221  Low MDM     OR 40-54 min physician time  
• 99222  Moderate MDM OR 55-74 min physician time  
• 99223  High MDM     OR 75 min + physician time  

• 99220  (Deleted 1-Jan-2023) – do not use. Observation admits now share 99221-99223.  

Remember: Choose the HIGHER of MDM vs. Time, but you must meet at least one column completely.

================================================================
6. RAPID ALGORITHM

1. Admit order + attending role? NO → use consult/ED/subsequent codes.  
2. ≥ 75 min total work today? YES → 99223 (document minutes) → STOP.  
3. If < 75 min, are ALL THREE MDM elements HIGH? YES → 99223 → STOP.  
4. Otherwise: Moderate MDM → 99222; Low MDM → 99221.

================================================================
7. REAL-WORLD MINI-CASES

A. Chest Pain with benign work-up  
• ECG normal, Trop neg x2, NSAID given, discharge plan tomorrow.  
• Time 38 min, MDM Low.  
Correct code: 99221 — NOT 99223.  
Key lesson: Extensive Hx/Exam ≠ higher code without high MDM or 75 min.

B. Unstable Angina  
• Trop 12 ng/mL, ST depression, IV heparin, cardiology discussion, cath planned.  
• MDM High (problems high risk, extensive data, high risk).  
• Time 46 min.  
Correct code: 99223 via MDM path (time <75 min, but MDM is High).

C. Complex Goals-of-Care Meeting  
• Metastatic CA, code-status discussion with family, palliative plan.  
• Total same-day physician time 78 min (majority counseling).  
• Data minimal, risk high but assume Moderate.  
Correct code: 99223 via TIME path.

================================================================
8. COMMON TRIP WIRES & HOW TO AVOID THEM

1. “Extended history + detailed exam” coding up: Not allowed—ignore exam bullets, focus on MDM/time.  
2. Using 99223 for Day-2 progress notes. Use 99231-99233 after the calendar date flips.  
3. Forgetting to DOCUMENT minutes or high-MDM evidence. If it isn’t written, it didn’t happen.  
4. Consultants labeling themselves “attending.” Add modifier ‑AI to true attending to distinguish.  
5. Billing deleted 99220 for observation admits—use 99221-99223.

================================================================
9. PEARL TO REMEMBER
If you cannot honestly say “Life-/organ-threatening complexity OR I personally worked ≥ 75 minutes,” you cannot bill 99223—no matter how beautiful the ROS and physical exam look.

CPT code 99223 is for a comprehensive level of history-taking and examination for patients in hospitals. 99221 is for a detailed history, 99222 is for an expanded problem-focused history, and 99220 is for observation or inpatient hospital care.

CPT.description: Excision and Destruction Procedures on the Vestibule of Mouth Summary: The provider excises a lesion or area of damaged or diseased tissue of the mucosa, a membrane lining the anterior most part of the mouth, and the submucosa, the layer beneath the mucosa. This procedure does not include repair of the surgical wound.

Excision and Destruction Procedures on the Vestibule of Mouth Summary: In this procedure, the provider eradicates a lesion present in the vestibule of the mouth using various techniques, except for excision.
CPT.explanation: 40820 pertains to sialolithotomy; by incision into duct.

CPT.description: Established Patient Summary: The provider sees an established patient for an office visit or other outpatient visit involving evaluation and management. The visit involves a straightforward level of medical decision making, and/or the provider spends 10 or more minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99201 is used for a problem-focused history and examination for new patients in an office or outpatient setting. 99212 is for established patients, 99203 is for a detailed history, and 99204 is for a comprehensive history.

CPT.description: Established Patient Summary: The provider sees an established patient for an office visit or other outpatient visit involving evaluation and management. The visit involves a moderate level of medical decision making, and/or the provider spends 30 minutes or more of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99213 is used for an expanded problem-focused history and examination for established patients. 99212 is for a problem-focused history, 99214 is for a detailed history, and 99215 is for a comprehensive history.

CPT.description: Established Patient Summary: The provider sees an established patient for an office visit or other outpatient visit involving evaluation and management. The visit involves a low level of medical decision making, and/or the provider spends 20 or more minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation:
CPT 99213  –  Established patient, Office/Outpatient visit  
Current (2021-forward) E/M rules

1. What qualifies?
   • EITHER Low-level Medical Decision Making (MDM) – OR – 20-29 minutes of total physician/qualified health-care professional (QHP) time on the date of service.  
   • History and examination are performed “as medically appropriate” but are NOT scored. Do not try to count HPI elements or exam bullets; that methodology was retired.

2. Key components for LOW-LEVEL MDM  
   • 2 or more self-limited or minor problems ‑OR- 1 stable chronic illness ‑OR- 1 acute, uncomplicated illness or injury.  
   • Limited data review/ordering (e.g., 1 external note, 1 test, or simple lab panel).  
   • Low risk of morbidity (OTC treatment, simple prescription management, physical therapy, etc.).

3. Typical visit clues
   • Follow-up for hypertension, reflux, mild asthma, minor rash, medication adjustment, etc.  
   • Physician reviews current meds, asks about symptom progress, performs a focused exam, possibly orders/refills a routine prescription.

4. Typical total time
   • 20–29 minutes spent face-to-face AND/OR on the same day in chart review, documentation, orders, patient communication, etc.

5. Common confusions

   99212  (Straightforward MDM or 10-19 min)  
   • Usually 1 self-limited/minor problem, no prescription management, minimal data reviewed.  
   • Example: re-check of a resolved URI, advice to continue home care, no new meds.

   99214  (Moderate MDM or 30-39 min)  
   • 1 chronic illness with exacerbation or 2+ stable chronic illnesses, or acute illness with systemic symptoms; moderate data; moderate drug-therapy risk.  
   • Example: uncontrolled diabetes requiring med change and review of CMP, A1c, and ophthalmology note.

   99215  (High MDM or 40-54 min)  
   • Severe exacerbations, high-risk medication monitoring (e.g., warfarin with INR issues), decision regarding hospitalization, extensive data review.

   Warning: A “limited exam” plus med review does NOT automatically equal 99212. If prescription drug management is involved or if two minor problems are addressed, LOW-level MDM is met → 99213.

6. Documentation tips
   • State problems addressed and status.  
   • Note any prescription changes or counseling.  
   • Briefly list data reviewed/ordered.  
   • Record total time when selecting code by time.

7. Do not down-code
   • If you meet LOW-level MDM (or 20-29 min) but document 99212, revenue is lost and quality measures may be impacted.

Mnemonic: “1 stable problem + Rx = 213” (read “2-13”).

CPT.description: Established Patient Summary: The provider sees an established patient for an office visit or other outpatient visit involving evaluation and management. The visit involves a high level of medical decision making, and/or the provider spends 40 or more minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99213 is used for an expanded problem-focused history and examination for established patients. 99212 is for a problem-focused history, 99214 is for a detailed history, and 99215 is for a comprehensive history.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Kidney Summary: Nephrectomy is a surgical procedure for removal of a kidney or part of a kidney.
CPT.explanation: The correct code, 50200, refers to a renal biopsy. The other codes are: 50220 - Nephrectomy, 50225 - Delayed nephrostogram, and 50230 - Nephrectomy, partial.

CPT.description: Anesthesia for Intrathoracic Procedures Summary: The provider performs anesthesia services for a patient undergoing closed chest procedures including bronchoscopy, which means viewing the windpipe for investigation. This code includes procedures that are not specifically described by another anesthesia code.
CPT.explanation: Code 00524 is specific to anesthesia for intrathoracic procedures. Code 00520 is more general and is used for procedures within the thorax, 00522 for lung surgeries, and 00526 for heart and coronary artery surgeries.

CPT.description: Anesthesia for Intrathoracic Procedures Summary: The provider performs anesthesia services for a patient undergoing a closed chest procedure involving a needle biopsy of the pleura, which is the double–layered membrane covering the lungs.
CPT.explanation: Code 00524 is specific to anesthesia for intrathoracic procedures. Code 00520 is more general and is used for procedures within the thorax, 00522 for lung surgeries, and 00526 for heart and coronary artery surgeries.

CPT.description: Anesthesia for Intrathoracic Procedures Summary: The provider performs anesthesia services for a patient undergoing the closed chest procedure of pneumocentesis in which another provider inserts a needle into the lung to drain the fluid contents.
CPT.explanation: Code 00524 is specific to anesthesia for intrathoracic procedures. Code 00520 is more general and is used for procedures within the thorax, 00522 for lung surgeries, and 00526 for heart and coronary artery surgeries.

CPT.description: Excision Procedures on the Tongue and Floor of Mouth Summary: In this procedure, the provider makes an incision at the base of the tongue and excises the frenum.

CPT.description: Incision Procedures on the Vestibule of Mouth Summary: The provider drains fluid from an abscess, cyst, or hematoma from the vestibule or anterior most portion of the oral cavity of the patient’s mouth. This code is applicable if the procedure requires extended time or the case is complex or complicated. The operative report should indicate the complexity involved and the provider’s additional time.

Incision Procedures on the Vestibule of Mouth Summary: The provider incises the labial frenum, the tag of tissue in the center of the upper or the lower lip that attaches the lip to the gums of the patient. The provider does not remove the frenum. The provider commonly performs this procedure to release a tight frenum and its surrounding tissues.
Anesthesia for Procedures on the Head Summary: The provider performs anesthesia services for a patient undergoing a plastic repair of cleft lip.
CPT.explanation: Code 00144 represents anesthesia for an inguinal hernia repair. Code 00102 is typically used for anesthesia during eyelid surgeries, 00145 for anesthesia during facial nerve surgeries, and 00148 for anesthesia during neck surgeries.

CPT.description: Anesthesia for Procedures on the Head Summary: The provider performs anesthesia services for a patient undergoing a corneal transplant.
CPT.explanation: Code 00144 represents anesthesia for an inguinal hernia repair. Code 00102 is typically used for anesthesia during eyelid surgeries, 00145 for anesthesia during facial nerve surgeries, and 00148 for anesthesia during neck surgeries.

CPT.description: Anesthesia for Procedures on the Head Summary: The provider performs anesthesia services for a patient undergoing vitreoretinal surgery.
CPT.explanation: Code 00144 represents anesthesia for an inguinal hernia repair. Code 00102 is typically used for anesthesia during eyelid surgeries, 00145 for anesthesia during facial nerve surgeries, and 00148 for anesthesia during neck surgeries.

CPT.description: Anesthesia for Procedures on the Head Summary: The provider performs anesthesia services for a patient undergoing an ophthalmoscopy.
CPT.explanation: Code 00144 represents anesthesia for an inguinal hernia repair. Code 00102 is typically used for anesthesia during eyelid surgeries, 00145 for anesthesia during facial nerve surgeries, and 00148 for anesthesia during neck surgeries.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Ultrasound Procedures of the Pelvis Obstetrical Summary: In this procedure, the provider performs an ultrasound of a pregnant uterus for examination of the first or a single fetus and to examine the mother after the first trimester, or more than 14 weeks of pregnancy, using a transabdominal approach.
CPT.explanation: Code 76805 is used for a routine obstetric ultrasound of a fetus. The other codes represent different types of ultrasound services and are not specifically for a routine obstetric ultrasound.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Ultrasound Procedures of the Pelvis Obstetrical Summary: In this add–on procedure, the provider performs a transabdominal ultrasound to examine each additional gestation sac, or fetus, after the first trimester.

Diagnostic Ultrasound Procedures of the Pelvis Obstetrical Summary: The provider performs a limited examination of the fetus using ultrasound. The provider performs the examination of certain parameters for one or more fetuses.
Diagnostic Ultrasound Procedures of the Pelvis Obstetrical Summary: The provider reexamines the fetus to follow up on a prior abnormal transabdominal ultrasound.
Other Procedures on the Nose Summary: The provider uses a complex or extensive approach to stop a heavy nosebleed caused by a vessel in the front area of the nose.
CPT.explanation: 30903 is the CPT code for control nasal hemorrhage, posterior, complex (e.g., therapeutic endoscopy, posterior nasal packs).

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Chest Summary: In this diagnostic procedure, the provider performs a computed tomography, or CT, examination of the thorax without using contrast material.
CPT.explanation: Code 71260 is for a CT of the chest with contrast. 71250 is without contrast, 71270 is with and without contrast, and 71275 is for a CT angiography of the chest.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Chest Summary: In this diagnostic procedure, the provider performs a computed tomography, or CT, examination of the thorax using contrast material.
CPT.explanation: Code 71260 is for a CT of the chest with contrast. 71250 is without contrast, 71270 is with and without contrast, and 71275 is for a CT angiography of the chest.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Chest Summary: In this diagnostic procedure, the provider performs a computed tomography, or CT, examination of the thorax without using contrast material. He then follows with contrast material and takes more images.
CPT.explanation: Code 71260 is for a CT of the chest with contrast. 71250 is without contrast, 71270 is with and without contrast, and 71275 is for a CT angiography of the chest.

CPT.description: Diagnostic Radiology (Diagnostic Imaging) Procedures of the Chest Summary: In this procedure, the provider performs a computed tomographic angiography, or CTA imaging of the chest to get detailed images of the blood vessels but not the heart. He performs this study using a contrast material injection and may also take non contrast images of the blood vessels as well.
CPT.explanation: Code 71260 is for a CT of the chest with contrast. 71250 is without contrast, 71270 is with and without contrast, and 71275 is for a CT angiography of the chest.

CPT.description: Psychotherapy Services and Procedures Summary: In this service, the provider performs psychotherapy, a series of techniques for treating the psychiatric disorders of the patient. The treatment session with the patient typically lasts for anywhere between16 to 37 minutes.
CPT.explanation: The CPT code 90832 is used to describe individual psychotherapy for 30 minutes. The other codes are for different durations or types of psychotherapy sessions.

CPT.description: Psychotherapy Services and Procedures Summary: In this service, the provider performs psychotherapy, a series of techniques for treating the psychiatric disorders of the patient. The treatment session with the patient typically lasts for anywhere between 38 to 52 minutes.

Psychotherapy Services and Procedures Summary: In this service, the provider performs psychotherapy, a series of technique for treating the psychiatric disorders of the patient. The treatment session typically lasts for a minimum of 53 minutes or more.

Psychotherapy for Crisis Services and Procedures Summary: In this service, the provider performs psychotherapy for a crisis situation when the patient is in a life–threatening state and needs immediate attention. The treatment session typically lasts anywhere between 30 to 74 minutes.

Endoscopy Procedures on the Rectum Summary: The provider examines the colon and rectum using a colonoscope, a flexible tube with a camera at its inserted end. If he sees any areas of abnormal mucosa or tissue, he takes samples using a brush passed through the scope or irrigates the area with warm saline and aspirates the washings through the scope. He sends the specimens to the laboratory for diagnostic analysis.
CPT.explanation: The correct CPT code for a diagnostic colonoscopy is 45378. Code 45379 represents colonoscopy with removal of a foreign body. Code 45380 represents colonoscopy with biopsy, and 45381 represents colonoscopy with direct submucosal injection.

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Rectum Summary: The provider examines the colon and rectum using a colonoscope, a tubular instrument with a light source and camera, which he inserts through the rectum to look for a blockage. He identifies and removes foreign bodies, such as swallowed objectives that could damage or obstruct the colon.
CPT.explanation: The correct CPT code for a diagnostic colonoscopy is 45378. Code 45379 represents colonoscopy with removal of a foreign body. Code 45380 represents colonoscopy with biopsy, and 45381 represents colonoscopy with direct submucosal injection.

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Rectum Summary: The provider examines the rectum and colon using a flexible colonoscope, a tubular instrument with a light source and camera, to look for the cause of a patient's symptoms, which may include diarrhea, constipation, rectal bleeding, or abdominal pain. He excises one or more suspicious areas of tissue using biopsy forceps and submits the specimens for laboratory analysis.
CPT.explanation: The correct CPT code for a diagnostic colonoscopy is 45378. Code 45379 represents colonoscopy with removal of a foreign body. Code 45380 represents colonoscopy with biopsy, and 45381 represents colonoscopy with direct submucosal injection.

CPT.description: Endoscopy Procedures on the Rectum Summary: The provider inserts a flexible endoscope into the anus and navigates the scope through the entire colon. The provider performs one or more injections into the submucosa (the tissue below the mucous membrane).
CPT.explanation: The correct CPT code for a diagnostic colonoscopy is 45378. Code 45379 represents colonoscopy with removal of a foreign body. Code 45380 represents colonoscopy with biopsy, and 45381 represents colonoscopy with direct submucosal injection.

CPT.description: New or Established Patient Summary: The provider sees a patient for an initial hospital inpatient or observation care visit involving evaluation and management (E/M). The visit involves a moderate level of medical decision making or the provider spends at least 55 minutes of total time on the encounter on a single date.
CPT.explanation: CPT code 99223 is for a comprehensive level of history-taking and examination for patients in hospitals. 99221 is for a detailed history, 99222 is for an expanded problem-focused history, and 99220 is for observation or inpatient hospital care.

CPT.description: Intraocular Lens Procedures Summary: The provider inserts an intraocular lens prosthesis after extracapsular cataract extraction using complex techniques and devices. He may perform this by means of an iris expansion device, providing support to the intraocular lens, or capsulorrhexis. This procedure is done without the use of an endoscopic laser probe to shrink the ciliary processes, a procedure to treat glaucoma.

Intraocular Lens Procedures Summary: The provider inserts an artificial lens after removing an extracapsular cataract by aspiration or use of ultrasonic waves. This procedure is done without the use of an endoscopic laser probe to shrink the ciliary processes, a procedure to treat glaucoma.
CPT.explanation: The CPT code 66984 represents extracapsular cataract removal with insertion of intraocular lens prosthesis. The other options are other ophthalmologic procedures but not specific to the described scenario.

CPT.description: Intraocular Lens Procedures Summary: The provider removes the cataract lens and capsule as one and then inserts a lens prosthesis. The goal of the procedure is to correct a cataract, an opacity of the lens that affects the vision of the eye.
Intraocular Lens Procedures Summary: The provider inserts an intraocular lens into the eye of a patient who had previously had cataract removal.

Hematology and Coagulation Procedures Summary: The lab analyst performs a blood count on the red and white blood cells and platelets also known as thrombocytes. He also determines the hemoglobin, typically by spectrophotometry, and the hematocrit, or packed red cell volume, by calculation in a whole blood sample.
CPT.explanation: Code 85025 is for a complete blood count (CBC) with differential. 85027 is for a basic CBC without differential, while 85029 and 85023 are not specific to the CBC with differential.

CPT.description: Hematology and Coagulation Procedures Summary: A complete blood count (better known as a CBC) is a blood test request by a doctor that provides detailed information about various types of cells in a patient's blood. Usually a pathologist or a technician conducts the test and provides the results of CBC to the requesting doctor. The blood is drawn from the patient's vein using a syringe and is stored in a test tube containing an anticoagulant (usually EDTA or citrate) to prevent clotting and transported to laboratory.  Nowadays, most often, the cell counting process is done in an automated way using an instrument known as an "automated analyzer". The automatic cell counter counts the number of different cells in the blood and the results are printed out for review by the physician.
CPT.explanation: Code 85025 is for a complete blood count (CBC) with differential. 85027 is for a basic CBC without differential, while 85029 and 85023 are not specific to the CBC with differential.

CPT.explanation: Code 00860 is used for anesthesia during lower abdominal procedures, including obstetric ultrasonography. Code 00864 represents anesthesia during cesarean delivery, 00862 during vaginal delivery, and 00868 during advanced labor and delivery procedures.
